RA well the EU reitterated on monday that diesel cars will soon be a thing of the past apparently, which platinum was used in its catalytic converters before Palladium took over. So platinum stockpiles have soared, prices have dropped and lots of mines are having to close. Platinum is popular in asian jewellery markets but not popular enough to use the surplus. The only way I could see platinum going up is if the 10 major miners formed an opec-esqe organisation to limit supply but even then, 25% of the platinum supply line is from recycled plat.

11:15 am

SocGen incoming:

BE11:16am

The market should respond positively to these new targets which are well ahead of current consensus and our estimates. All else equal, we estimate the new guidance could add 10% to the current 2020 Bloomberg consensus EPS and 9% to our current estimates. On top of this, we expect the market to welcome the focus on portfolio management. A strategic review of the underperforming distribution business is timely and has potential to improve return ratios, in our view. CRH stock looks attractively valued to us, trading on a FCFE yield (pre M&A and dividends) of 6.0% for 2018e and 7.0% for 2019e.

Soundbuy CRH - Irish listing too..........

And Davy.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Key to CRH’s announcement today is that it expects to generate
unutilised financial capacity of €7bn over the next four years
through its ongoing focus on operational efficiency and financial
management. This is un-paralleled in the sector and provides the
company with significant value creation potential. Assuming all of
this cash is used for acquisition would create at least €12 per
share (40%) in incremental value. In the unlikely event that all of
the cash is returned to shareholders, this could add c.30% to the
share price. The company’s ability to generate strong and
sustained cashflow has long been underappreciated. We expect
to see this potential reflected in the share price and valuation.

On topline assumptions consistent with the company’s market outlook (3-4% p.a.), we currently forecast a margin of 14.4% in 2021, the difference coming from the improvement initiatives announced today. A 15.9% margin in 2021 would imply €4.7bn of EBITDA on our estimates, implying a 10% upgrade vs. our existing forecast of €4.3bn and 10% CAGR on our 2018E of €3.5bn.

BE11:26am

Johnson Matthey's H2'18 results were in line with consensus throughout; reporting sales (ex. metals) of £1,993m, and EBIT £275m, versus cons. of £1,993m and £273m respectively. Johnson Matthey's FY'18 dividend of 80p was 2.5% ahead of consensus (78p). Divisionally Clean Air was ~5% ahead at EBIT given strength in HDD markets, as well as LDV, offsetting the weakness in Health, which was impacted by inventory destocking, and optimising production footprint. YE net debt of £679m was down £212m from 1H ’18 level of £891m, and comfortably below cons. of £797m. This was driven by lower capex of £217m (vs FY ‘18 guidance of £285m) due to capex discipline and project phasing. Net debt incl. pensions was £725m, or 1.1x EBITDA, below JM’s target range of 1.5-2x. Working capital outflows were £158m, impacted by a precious metal outflow of £82m from higher prices and volumes. Guidance calls for mid to high single digit EBIT growth at constant currency, implying at the midpoint FY'18/19 EBIT of £564m; which when adjusted for £6m FX headwind is a touch ahead of consensus (£556m). Bottom line: fears over weak cash flow and escalating capex have not materialised, margins are improving in Clean Air, and new guidance underpins consensus and may yet prove conservative. In cathode materials, the company remains confident around its emerging eLNO technology, and sees its proposed 10k mtpa project as "just the beginning". For the returns and growth on offer, JM remains one of the most attractive stocks in EU chemicals, we think. Overweight.

wayneJ Mouselet - My understanding is that the profit margins etc and product mix for the more prestigious car makers (in the UK think JLR; and in Germany all the prestige names) have been skewed to diesel.
RA but ford and vw and many others are shifting the focus to electric

BE11:39am

Firstgroup’s FY18 results indicate in line underlying trading, but with three important non-trading developments. 1. Tim O’Toole is stepping down as CEO. 2. The group has taken a £106m provision on Transpennine. 3. A $387m impairment charge has been taken on Greyhound. The group delivered a £110.5m net cash inflow (ex-rail) in the period, with ND/EBITDA down to 2.1x. Our forecasts are reduced by 8-11% at the EPS level. While we are OW on valuation, we clearly acknowledge the level of risk involved in the investment case. We reinstate our rating at OW following a period of restriction; our Dec-18 price target is 133p vs. 163p prior to the restriction.

BE11:40am

We expect FY19e to be a poor year for ex-rail cash flow, due mainly to higher CAPEX. In particular, we expect CAPEX to rise to c.£560m in FY19e vs £423m in FY18, offset by rail working capital inflows and lower interest costs. Despite this we still expect group FCF of £105m, a yield of 7.8%. Given this, we reinstate our OW recommendation, although our TP is now 133p. Our EPS forecasts fall 8-11%, mainly due to Greyhound and Rail.

RA all diamonds can be produced in a lab, if you then crush that lab under millions of tonnes of pressure
J in Tokyo When Tesla say they have near-zero cobalt batteries, do they mean Panasonic batteries? Or is this independent of the Japanese?
alewis2005 morning people
BE11:41am

And RBC.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Companies just out of a bid situation tend to pull-out all the stops to deliver a big EPS beat – so the 12.3p EPS vs. BBG cons 12.1p (RBCe 11.9p) was just a 2% beat. We think the lurking risk of a forced break-up (if profits don’t perform and the share price slips back again) means historical precedent suggests a beat should be delivered after Apollo’s rejected approach. Still missing forecasts ‘in year’: Adjusted EPS at 12.3p missed start of year expectations by 13.3% vs. 14.2p RBCe (BBG cons 14.2p). In year EPS slippage is a consistent company trait in our data (over 20 years). Key to investment quality will be delivering a year of upward or stable in-year EPS momentum. FY18 did not deliver this, again.
Some corporate action ambition emerges: Welcome news (to us) today are proposals to; (1) An onerous contract provision for TPE losses (£106m, which will also remove minority effects from EPS); (2) A write down of Greyhound assets by £277m and a deeper review under way, and (3) A restructuring of the company management.
Based on track record, this will be a ‘show me’ story though as the shares trade at 9x FY18, and likely around 11-12x FY19E pension adjusted PER – a premium to GOG LN (10x), similar to (more diverse, cash generative) NEX LN, and a 40% multiple premium to DPS paying SGC LN – suggesting a major turnaround/beat vs. FY19E-20E BBG consensus needs to be delivered and delivered – or a premium bid is required.
No new potential industrial or financial bidders have emerged so proof of delivery is the key here, in our view.
Net Debt at £1,070m compares to RBCe £1,064m (not rail adjusted) and BBG consensus £1,111m. The difference vs. BBG cons is worth 3p/share debt to equity transfer.
Looking to 2018/19E we see cons op profits (underlying) settling at £315m-£325m – down 4-7% from BBG cons £339m – with UK Bus likely at £58m-£63m, UK Rail likely at £39m-£45m, and Student likely at $225m-$235m, Transit at $85m-$95m and Greyhound – subject to the review – likely at $15m-$20m.

11:51 am

The Q1 trading update is disappointing, with LFL in negative
territory, and we are downgrading to slightly below management
guidance. Card volumes remain a concern: Valentine’s and
Mothers’ Day went well but everyday cards are lacking
inspiration. Non-card growth has slowed back to flat LFL.
CARD needs a bounce back in LFL to achieve its guidance and
we think, with the High Street shopper likely to stay a little
cautious, that this is unlikely, hence the 3% downgrade. The
special is confirmed today but will be at the bottom end of the
5-10p range, in our view. Cash generation does remain an
attraction here but the top line of the cashflow keeps falling and
that’s going to hold the shares back. Hold.
